text: researchers at Emory University have
developed a fluorescent tension sensor
that measures how hard a cell membrane
receptor tugs on a ligand during binding
in this video you see a cell or at least
its membrane drift down toward the
sensor surface when it contacts the
sensor molecule a receptor in the
membrane pulls on the sensor causing it
to fluoresce with increasing brightness
this scheme works because of the design
of the tension sensor at one end is a
biotin moiety which is responsible for
tethering the molecule to a glass
surface at the other end is epidermal
growth factor a peptide that regulates
cell growth and proliferation as well as
a fluorescent dye called alexa fluor in
between is a polyethylene glycol linker
that stretches like a spring let's take
a look at the sensor surface again the
tension sensor sticks to the glass
service via a biotin streptavidin
linkage streptavidin a protein is read
this biotin streptavidin linkage is one
of the strongest non covalent bonds
known in nature the stripped avidin
protein is also decorated with a
quencher molecule indicated by a little
blue bead when the receptor in the cell
contacts its peptide target it pulls on
the tension sensor as the pair bind when
this happens the fluorescent diet the
tip of the tension sensor moves away
from the quencher surface as a result
fluorescence intensity increases the
researchers monitor this event with a
conventional fluorescence microscope and
can map out the forces exerted across a
cell over time
